children: Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common form of meningitis in patients with AIDS, who typically present with headache. Most patients have a CD4 cell count of less than 100/μL. The diagnosis is based on detection of cryptococcal antigen in the
in the CSF. Serum cryptococcal antigen is positive in 95% of patients. The opening CSF pressure is typically elevated.

Choose amphotericin B plus flucytosine for induction treatment of meningitis followed by fluconazole maintenance therapy. Maintenance therapy is indicated for patients with AIDS and cryptococcal meningitis until the CD4 cell count is ≥100/μL for ≥3 months and the viral load is suppressed.
